top_box.author: Pamela Núñez
freeform_fields:
¿Sientes que tu vida amorosa es un desastre o temes que lo sea? ¿Te preguntas constantemente qué hice mal o cómo evito equivocarme? En este libro, Pamela Núñez te entrega las respuestas.
"¿Así que tu vida amorosa también es un desastre? ¿Perteneces al club de los que ha tomado muchas decisiones estúpidas por amor, de las cuales, siendo muy benevolente, ahora te arrepientes de la mitad?". Estas son algunas de las preguntas que dan inicio a Cómo arruinar tu vida amorosa... ¡o no!, un manual que no pretende darte el paso a paso de cómo encontrar pareja, sino que ser esa guía que necesitas para mantener tu vida direccionada hacia el buen amor, sin perderte en el camino.
Según la ciencia, el cultivo de relaciones saludables es uno de los mayores predictores de felicidad. Este fundamental dato, sumado a más de veinte años de experiencia viendo cómo los patrones vinculares de sus pacientes impactan en su bienestar, llevaron a la psicóloga Pamela Núñez –especialista en ansiedad, estrés y calidad de vida–, a diseñar una herramienta para educar sobre, quizás, el tema que más convoca a los seres humanos: el amor.
Con el humor como su principal aliado, la autora nos presenta a la adorable llama del amor y a su opuesto, la sufrida llama del drama, como metáfora del amor saludable... o no. Así, creó un Detectómetro que, por medio de doce principios, te mostrará si estás en ruta hacia el destino que todos anhelan o si, por el contrario, vas directo a desbarrancarte.
Si quieres mantener encendida la llama del amor en tu vida, este libro es para ti.

top_box.author: Elvira Mass
freeform_fields: This detailed book delves into the diverse techniques and applications to target, isolate, image, phenotype, and analyze tissue-resident and monocyte-derived macrophages. The contents aim to describe the current knowledge about macrophage development and function which forces the scientific field to move beyond the previously described M1/M2 macrophage paradigm to be able to dissect macrophage functions within their specific niches during health and disease. Written for the highly successful series, chapters include introductions to their respective topics, lists of the necessary materials and reagents, step-by-step and readily reproducible laboratory protocols, and tips on troubleshooting and avoiding known pitfalls. Thorough and practical, provides scientists entering the macrophage field with information and tools that allow them to dive into the state-of-the-art methodology used in this vital field.

top_box.author: Alessandra Lucia Zollo; Edoardo Bucchignani
freeform_fields:
In-flight icing, i.e. the accretion of ice on airplane’s surfaces during flight, is caused by supercooled water droplets that freeze instantly when they impact the airframe and it represents a critical meteorological risk to aviation as it affects aircraft performance, stability and controllability. Therefore, the remote detection of weather conditions leading to in-flight icing is a goal of great interest to the scientific community.
In 2017, the Meteorological Laboratory of CIRA has developed a first satellite-based tool for in-flight icing detection in collaboration with Italian Air Force Meteorological Service. This tool is based on several high-resolution satellite products of Meteosat Second Generation (MSG) and a set of experimental curves and envelopes describing the interrelationship of icing-related cloud variables that represent the icing reference certification rules, namely Appendix C to FAA 14 CFR Part 25 / EASA CS-25. However, Appendix C data do not consider Supercooled Large Droplets (SLD), which have been the cause of tragic accidents over the last decades and that have been introduced in new certification procedures and guidelines through the Appendix O, effective as of 2015. In the framework of the H2020 EU project SENS4ICE (SENSors and certifiable hybrid architectures for safer aviation in ICing Environment) started in 2019, CIRA is working on a further maturation of the previously developed icing detection algorithm, in order to consider also Appendix O Icing Conditions. The developed tool is targeted to identify areas potentially affected by in flight icing hazard, giving an estimate of the altitude and of the severity of the phenomenon (light, moderate, severe) with indication of possible SLD conditions.
In the present work an overall description of the implemented tool is provided along with an analysis of its performance. Due to the lack of suitable in-situ observations of icing conditions, a complete validation of the developed product is challenging. A comparison with significant weather charts has been performed and other validation activities based on the comparison with soundings data are ongoing, showing quite good results. Furthermore, this tool is currently being used in the framework of the SENS4ICE flight test campaign (scheduled in April 2023), which represents a good opportunity to evaluate its performance in environmental icing conditions. During the flight tests, information on monitoring of icing conditions are provided in the pre-flight phase and updated in near-real time. The outcomes of the flight test campaign will be exploited to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the algorithm.
Acknowledgment: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement N° 824253 (SENS4ICE project).
meta_information: An aviation support tool for satellite remote detection of in-flight icing.

file_unified_data.stripped_description_best:
In-flight icing, i.e. the accretion of ice on airplane’s surfaces during flight, is caused by supercooled water droplets that freeze instantly when they impact the airframe and it represents a critical meteorological risk to aviation as it affects aircraft performance, stability and controllability. Therefore, the remote detection of weather conditions leading to in-flight icing is a goal of great interest to the scientific community.
In 2017, the Meteorological Laboratory of CIRA has developed a first satellite-based tool for in-flight icing detection in collaboration with Italian Air Force Meteorological Service. This tool is based on several high-resolution satellite products of Meteosat Second Generation (MSG) and a set of experimental curves and envelopes describing the interrelationship of icing-related cloud variables that represent the icing reference certification rules, namely Appendix C to FAA 14 CFR Part 25 / EASA CS-25. However, Appendix C data do not consider Supercooled Large Droplets (SLD), which have been the cause of tragic accidents over the last decades and that have been introduced in new certification procedures and guidelines through the Appendix O, effective as of 2015. In the framework of the H2020 EU project SENS4ICE (SENSors and certifiable hybrid architectures for safer aviation in ICing Environment) started in 2019, CIRA is working on a further maturation of the previously developed icing detection algorithm, in order to consider also Appendix O Icing Conditions. The developed tool is targeted to identify areas potentially affected by in flight icing hazard, giving an estimate of the altitude and of the severity of the phenomenon (light, moderate, severe) with indication of possible SLD conditions.
In the present work an overall description of the implemented tool is provided along with an analysis of its performance. Due to the lack of suitable in-situ observations of icing conditions, a complete validation of the developed product is challenging. A comparison with significant weather charts has been performed and other validation activities based on the comparison with soundings data are ongoing, showing quite good results. Furthermore, this tool is currently being used in the framework of the SENS4ICE flight test campaign (scheduled in April 2023), which represents a good opportunity to evaluate its performance in environmental icing conditions. During the flight tests, information on monitoring of icing conditions are provided in the pre-flight phase and updated in near-real time. The outcomes of the flight test campaign will be exploited to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the algorithm.
Acknowledgment: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement N° 824253 (SENS4ICE project).
file_unified_data.title_best: An aviation support tool for satellite remote detection of in-flight icing.

top_box.author: United States
freeform_fields: "Who's Who in the Roman World is a wide-ranging biographical survey of one of the greatest civilizations in history. Covering a period from the 5th century BC to AD 364, this is a guide to an era which continues to fascinate today. The figures represented come from all walks of Roman life and include some of history's most famous - not to mention infamous - figures as well as hitherto little-known, but no less fascinating, characters. The inclusion of cross-referencing, a glossary of terms, select bibliographies, a chronology and list of the emperors, maps, and an author's preface completes what is at once a superb reference resource and an enormously entertaining read."--BOOK JACKET
